pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:0.5: 17. The training rule on getting wool washed
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the Sakyan country at Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.2: At that time the monks from the group of six got nuns to wash, dye, and comb wool.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.3: Because of this work, the nuns neglected recitation, questioning, the higher morality, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.4: Mahāpajāpati Gotamī then approached the Buddha and bowed down to him.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.5: And the Buddha said to her, “Gotamī, I hope the nuns are heedful, energetic, and diligent?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.6: “How could the nuns be heedful, Venerable Sir?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.7: And she told him what was happening.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.9: The Buddha then instructed, inspired, and gladdened her with a teaching.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.10: She bowed down, circumambulated him with her right side toward him, and left.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.11: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha assembled and questioned the monks from the group of six:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.12: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.16: “Foolish men, people who are not related don’t know what’s appropriate and what’s inappropriate in dealing with each other, what’s inspiring behavior and what’s not.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.17: And still you got unrelated nuns to wash, dye, and comb wool.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.18: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.19: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.20: ‘If a monk gets an unrelated nun to wash, dye, or comb wool, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.24: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a complete Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.26: anyone who is not a descendant of one’s male ancestors going back seven generations, either on the mother’s side or on the father’s side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.28: she has been given the full ordination by both Sanghas.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.29: If he tells her to wash it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.30: When it has been washed, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.31: If he tells her to dye it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.32: When it has been dyed, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.33: If he tells her to comb it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.34: When it has been combed, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.35: The wool should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.36: “And, monks, it should be relinquished in this way. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.37: (To be expanded as in [Relinquishment 1](pli-tv-bu-vb-np1:3.2.5--3.2.29), with appropriate substitutions.)
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.38: ‘Venerables, this wool which I got washed by an unrelated nun is to be relinquished.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.39: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np17:1.42: ‘I give this wool back to you.’”
